elements.content: In recent years, the design and discovery of new metal-organic framework (MOF) platforms with distinct structural features and tunable chemical composition has remarkably enhanced by applying reticular chemistry rules and the molecular building block (MBB) approach. We targeted the synthesis of new rare earth (RE)-MOF platforms based on a rectangular-shaped 4-c linker, acting as a rigid organic MBB. Accordingly, we designed and synthesized the organic ligand 1,2,4,5-tetrakis­(4-carboxyphenyl)-3,6-dimethyl-benzene (H4 L), in which the two methyl groups attached to the central phenyl ring lock the four peripheral carboxyphenyl groups to an orthogonal/vertical position. We report here a new family of RE-MOFs featuring the novel inorganic building unit, RE4(μ3-O)2 (RE: Y3+, Tb3+, Dy3+, Ho3+, Er3+, and Yb3+), with planar D 2h symmetry. The rigid 4-c linker, H4 L, directs the in situ assembly of the unique 8-c RE4(μ3-O)2(COO)8 cluster, resulting in the formation of the first (4, 8)-c RE-MOFs with csq topology, RE-csq-MOF-1. The structures of the yttrium (Y-csq-MOF-1) and holmium (Ho-csq-MOF-1) analogues were determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. Y-csq-MOF-1 was successfully activated and tested for Xe/Kr separation. The results show that Y-csq-MOF-1 has high isosteric heat of adsorption for Xe (33.8 kJ mol–1), with high Xe/Kr selectivity (IAST 12.1, Henry 12.9) and good Xe uptake (1.94 mmol g–1 at 298 K and 1 bar), placing this MOF among the top-performing adsorbents for Xe/Kr separation.
elements.clean_text: In recent years, the design and discovery of new metal-organic framework (MOF) platforms with distinct structural features and tunable chemical composition has remarkably enhanced by applying reticular chemistry rules and the molecular building block (MBB) approach. We targeted the synthesis of new rare earth (RE)-MOF platforms based on a rectangular-shaped 4-c linker, acting as a rigid organic MBB. Accordingly, we designed and synthesized the organic ligand 1,2,4,5-tetrakis(4-carboxyphenyl)-3,6-dimethyl-benzene (H4 L), in which the two methyl groups attached to the central phenyl ring lock the four peripheral carboxyphenyl groups to an orthogonal/vertical position. We report here a new family of RE-MOFs featuring the novel inorganic building unit, RE4(μ3-O)2 (RE: Y3+, Tb3+, Dy3+, Ho3+, Er3+, and Yb3+), with planar D 2h  symmetry. The rigid 4-c linker, H4 L, directs the in situ assembly of the unique 8-c RE4(μ3-O)2(COO)8 cluster, resulting in the formation of the first (4, 8)-c RE-MOFs with csq topology, RE-csq-MOF-1. The structures of the yttrium (Y-csq-MOF-1) and holmium (Ho-csq-MOF-1) analogues were determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. Y-csq-MOF-1 was successfully activated and tested for Xe/Kr separation. The results show that Y-csq-MOF-1 has high isosteric heat of adsorption for Xe (33.8 kJ mol-1), with high Xe/Kr selectivity (IAST 12.1, Henry 12.9) and good Xe uptake (1.94 mmol g-1 at 298 K and 1 bar), placing this MOF among the top-performing adsorbents for Xe/Kr separation.

elements.content: The chemistry and applications of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) is one of the most fascinating and rapidly expanding fields in materials science. The modular nature of these hybrid solids, built from well-defined inorganic and organic building units, offers great opportunities for the construction of novel, highly crystalline open-framework materials with desired porosities and framework functionalities. MOFs can be rationally designed to a great extent following the reticular chemistry rules. A very successful implementation approach relies on the availability of organic and inorganic molecular building blocks (MBBs) that have well-defined geometric characteristics in terms of size, shape, and connectivity. Of particular interest are MBBs, the combination of which endows MOFs with simple topologies, such as the binodal edge-transitive nets (nets with one kind of edges). In fact, this kind of nets can be used as blueprints for the construction of MOFs with desired porosities and structural characteristics. For example, MOFs with nbo, rht, and tbo topologies based on dimeric Cu­(II) paddle wheels all possess highly energetic Cu­(II) unsaturated metal sites (Lewis acid sites) upon activation.In other cases, the terminal −OH/H2O groups on 8-connected Zr­(Hf)6 clusters in MOFs with scu, csq, flu, and the topologies or in defective UiO-type materials (i) offer Brønsted acidity, (ii) could act as grafting sites for the immobilization of catalytically active species, and (iii) their removal by thermal treatment leaves behind coordinatively unsaturated metal sites (Lewis acid sites), providing in this way unique opportunities for the development of heterogeneous single-site catalysts.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The chemistry and applications of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) is one of the most fascinating and rapidly expanding fields in materials science. The modular nature of these hybrid solids, built from well-defined inorganic and organic building units, offers great opportunities for the construction of novel, highly crystalline open-framework materials with desired porosities and framework functionalities. MOFs can be rationally designed to a great extent following the reticular chemistry rules. A very successful implementation approach relies on the availability of organic and inorganic molecular building blocks (MBBs) that have well-defined geometric characteristics in terms of size, shape, and connectivity. Of particular interest are MBBs, the combination of which endows MOFs with simple topologies, such as the binodal edge-transitive nets (nets with one kind of edges). In fact, this kind of nets can be used as blueprints for the construction of MOFs with desired porosities and structural characteristics. For example, MOFs with nbo, rht, and tbo topologies based on dimeric Cu(II) paddle wheels all possess highly energetic Cu(II) unsaturated metal sites (Lewis acid sites) upon activation.In other cases, the terminal -OH/H2O groups on 8-connected Zr(Hf)6 clusters in MOFs with scu, csq, flu, and the topologies or in defective UiO-type materials (i) offer Brønsted acidity, (ii) could act as grafting sites for the immobilization of catalytically active species, and (iii) their removal by thermal treatment leaves behind coordinatively unsaturated metal sites (Lewis acid sites), providing in this way unique opportunities for the development of heterogeneous single-site catalysts.

elements.content: Highly connected (≥6) symmetrical metal clusters are valuable MBBs in practicing reticular chemistry and target novel MOFs with important properties because their connectivity rules are compatible only with a limited number of nets. However, the bottleneck of this approach is the fact that the inorganic MBBs are not readily available and form in situ, usually under strict reaction conditions. For example, the important hexanuclear and nonanuclear rare earth (RE) clusters that are used for the construction of a number of fascinating structures with diverse topologies, including fcu, ftw, shp, gea, and alb, are accessible upon addition of 2-fluorobenzoic acid (2-FBA) to the initial reaction mixture. In another example, the synthesis of the recently reported pcu family of MOFs, based on 6-c octahedral [RE4(μ3-OH)4(COO)6]2+ clusters, requires that the carboxylate organic linkers have a primary amino group located at the ortho position to the coordinating carboxylate group and also a mixed solvent system (N,N′-dimethylformamide (DMF)/H2O).
elements.clean_text: Highly connected (≥6) symmetrical metal clusters are valuable MBBs in practicing reticular chemistry and target novel MOFs with important properties because their connectivity rules are compatible only with a limited number of nets. However, the bottleneck of this approach is the fact that the inorganic MBBs are not readily available and form in situ, usually under strict reaction conditions. For example, the important hexanuclear and nonanuclear rare earth (RE) clusters that are used for the construction of a number of fascinating structures with diverse topologies, including fcu, ftw, shp, gea, and alb, are accessible upon addition of 2-fluorobenzoic acid (2-FBA) to the initial reaction mixture. In another example, the synthesis of the recently reported pcu family of MOFs, based on 6-c octahedral [RE4(μ3-OH)4(COO)6]2+ clusters, requires that the carboxylate organic linkers have a primary amino group located at the ortho position to the coordinating carboxylate group and also a mixed solvent system (N,N'-dimethylformamide (DMF)/H2O).

elements.content: In addition to the above, the geometric characteristics of the organic ligand, in terms of size and connectivity (number and relative positioning of the coordinating groups), play an important role in accessing MOFs with a particular net and in fact, direct the formation of the inorganic MBBs with a connectivity that is compatible with this net. It is has been demonstrated that the successful implementation of reticular chemistry starts with the designed synthesis of the organic ligands and then with the choice of metal cations that have the potential to form in situ the desired inorganic MBBs or secondary building units (SBUs), in terms of connectivity and symmetry. This is one of the reasons why Zr- and Hf-based MOFs have attracted a great attention because they can form in situ the well-known hexanuclear cluster but with a different connectivity, such as 12-, 10-, 8-, or 6-c, which is compatible with the topology of different binodal edge-transitive nets, including fcu (12-c), ftw (12-c), shp (12-c), scu (8-c), csq (8-c), flu (8-c), ith (8-c), she (6-c), and hxg (6-c).
elements.clean_text: In addition to the above, the geometric characteristics of the organic ligand, in terms of size and connectivity (number and relative positioning of the coordinating groups), play an important role in accessing MOFs with a particular net and in fact, direct the formation of the inorganic MBBs with a connectivity that is compatible with this net. It is has been demonstrated that the successful implementation of reticular chemistry starts with the designed synthesis of the organic ligands and then with the choice of metal cations that have the potential to form in situ the desired inorganic MBBs or secondary building units (SBUs), in terms of connectivity and symmetry. This is one of the reasons why Zr- and Hf-based MOFs have attracted a great attention because they can form in situ the well-known hexanuclear cluster but with a different connectivity, such as 12-, 10-, 8-, or 6-c, which is compatible with the topology of different binodal edge-transitive nets, including fcu (12-c), ftw (12-c), shp (12-c), scu (8-c), csq (8-c), flu (8-c), ith (8-c), she (6-c), and hxg (6-c).

elements.content: Interestingly, although the same hexanuclear cluster exists with REs as an SBU in MOFs, it does not display the versatility in terms of connectivity observed in the case of Zr/Hf hexanuclear SBUs. Accordingly, in their vast majority, these are 12-c hexanuclear clusters, [RE6(μ3-OH)8(COO)12]2–, appeared in MOFs with fcu, ftw, and alb topologies. In a very rare example, 8-c [RE6(μ3-OH)8(COO)8]2+ clusters were found to coexist with nonanuclear [RE9(μ3-OH)12(μ3-O)2(COO)12]− clusters, forming a MOF with pek topology. Therefore, it would be highly desirable to develop synthetic strategies toward RE-based MOF families with different topologies, such as those found in Zr- and Hf-based MOFs, because unique structural features in terms of pore size, shape, and connectivity, as well as the spatial arrangement and the properties of the MBBs blocks (e.g., Lewis acid sites), could be coupled with important, inherent physical properties, originating from REs.
elements.clean_text: Interestingly, although the same hexanuclear cluster exists with REs as an SBU in MOFs, it does not display the versatility in terms of connectivity observed in the case of Zr/Hf hexanuclear SBUs. Accordingly, in their vast majority, these are 12-c hexanuclear clusters, [RE6(μ3-OH)8(COO)12]2-, appeared in MOFs with fcu, ftw, and alb  topologies. In a very rare example, 8-c [RE6(μ3-OH)8(COO)8]2+ clusters were found to coexist with nonanuclear [RE9(μ3-OH)12(μ3-O)2(COO)12]- clusters, forming a MOF with pek topology. Therefore, it would be highly desirable to develop synthetic strategies toward RE-based MOF families with different topologies, such as those found in Zr- and Hf-based MOFs, because unique structural features in terms of pore size, shape, and connectivity, as well as the spatial arrangement and the properties of the MBBs blocks (e.g., Lewis acid sites), could be coupled with important, inherent physical properties, originating from REs.

elements.content: Taking into account the importance of the organic linker in directing the assembly of the inorganic MBBs and in this way the overall framework topology, we designed and synthesized the rigid tetratopic carboxylate-based organic linker, 1,2,4,5-tetrakis­(4-carboxyphenyl)-3,6-dimethyl-benzene, denoted as H4 L (b). The two methyl groups attached to the central phenyl ring lock the four peripheral carboxyphenyl groups to an orthogonal/vertical position, making this organic ligand a rigid MBB. Looking at the three-dimensional (3D) binodal nets in the reticular chemistry structure resource database, in which only the connectivity and symmetry of the two different nodes are considered, this rectangular-shaped 4-c linker is compatible with several topologies, including the augmented shp, scu, csq, and she nets, when combined with symmetrical 12-, 8- (scu and csq), and 6-c inorganic MBBs, respectively. Therefore, this linker is well suited for exploring the synthesis of the corresponding RE-based MOF nets. Remarkably, using this linker as an organic MBB, a new family of RE-based MOFs with the csq topology was discovered and features a new, highly symmetric 8-c tetranuclear cluster, RE4(μ3-O)2(COO)8 (Y3+, Tb3+, Dy3+, Ho3+, Er3+, and Yb3+). Although all solids were obtained in single-crystal form, we report here the single-crystal structure of yttrium and holmium analogues, and we demonstrate the permanent porosity of yttrium by extensive gas-sorption measurements. In addition, this MOF, because of the presence of Lewis acid sites on the yttrium cluster, resulting from the removal of coordinated solvent molecules, shows a very high Xe/Kr selectivity of 12.1 at 298 K and 1 bar.
elements.clean_text: Taking into account the importance of the organic linker in directing the assembly of the inorganic MBBs and in this way the overall framework topology, we designed and synthesized the rigid tetratopic carboxylate-based organic linker, 1,2,4,5-tetrakis(4-carboxyphenyl)-3,6-dimethyl-benzene, denoted as H4 L (b). The two methyl groups attached to the central phenyl ring lock the four peripheral carboxyphenyl groups to an orthogonal/vertical position, making this organic ligand a rigid MBB. Looking at the three-dimensional (3D) binodal nets in the reticular chemistry structure resource database, in which only the connectivity and symmetry of the two different nodes are considered, this rectangular-shaped 4-c linker is compatible with several topologies, including the augmented shp, scu, csq, and she nets, when combined with symmetrical 12-, 8- (scu and csq), and 6-c inorganic MBBs, respectively. Therefore, this linker is well suited for exploring the synthesis of the corresponding RE-based MOF nets. Remarkably, using this linker as an organic MBB, a new family of RE-based MOFs with the csq topology was discovered and features a new, highly symmetric 8-c tetranuclear cluster, RE4(μ3-O)2(COO)8 (Y3+, Tb3+, Dy3+, Ho3+, Er3+, and Yb3+). Although all solids were obtained in single-crystal form, we report here the single-crystal structure of yttrium and holmium analogues, and we demonstrate the permanent porosity of yttrium by extensive gas-sorption measurements. In addition, this MOF, because of the presence of Lewis acid sites on the yttrium cluster, resulting from the removal of coordinated solvent molecules, shows a very high Xe/Kr selectivity of 12.1 at 298 K and 1 bar.

elements.content: Combination of the novel 8-c tetranuclear clusters RE4(μ3-O)2(-COO)8 (a) with the 4-c rectangular H4 L ligand (b) leads to the construction of RE-csq-MOF-1 series (c), displaying the augment csq-a net.
elements.clean_text: 1  Combination of the novel 8-c tetranuclear clusters RE4(μ3-O)2(-COO)8 (a) with the 4-c rectangular H4 L ligand (b) leads to the construction of RE-csq-MOF-1 series (c), displaying the augment csq-a net.

elements.content: An important discovery for the development of RE-MOFs, based on isolated clusters (hexanuclear and nonanuclear) made by the Eddaoudi group, was the use of 2-fluorobenzoic acid as a unique modulator that prevents the formation of the commonly observed chainlike RE building units and also promotes the crystallization of the resulting materials. This is in marked contrast to the modulators frequently applied in the case of Zr­(Hf) cluster-based MOFs, where benzoic and acetic acids are usually employed. Interestingly, in our case, we found that a mixture of acetic acid and 2-FBA is important to obtain high-quality single-crystalline materials (Table S1). Accordingly, solvothermal reactions in N,N′-dimethylformamide (DMF) between RE­(NO3)3·6H2O (RE: Y3+, Tb3+, Dy3+, Ho3+, Er3+, and Yb3+) and H4 L in the presence of excess acetic acid and 2-FBA afforded high-quality hexagonal-shaped single crystals. However, the selection of twin-free small crystals resulted in poor single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD), except for the yttrium and holmium analogues, where a successful SCXRD analysis was executed (Tables S2 and S3). All of the other RE analogues were found isostructural on the basis of their powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns (Figure S3). The phase purity of each RE-csq-MOF-1 was confirmed by whole profile pattern matching using the Le Bail method (Figure S4). The crystal structure of the Y-analogue is described in detail below.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

An important discovery for the development of RE-MOFs, based on isolated clusters (hexanuclear and nonanuclear) made by the Eddaoudi group, was the use of 2-fluorobenzoic acid as a unique modulator that prevents the formation of the commonly observed chainlike RE building units and also promotes the crystallization of the resulting materials. This is in marked contrast to the modulators frequently applied in the case of Zr(Hf) cluster-based MOFs, where benzoic and acetic acids are usually employed. Interestingly, in our case, we found that a mixture of acetic acid and 2-FBA is important to obtain high-quality single-crystalline materials (Table S1). Accordingly, solvothermal reactions in N,N'-dimethylformamide (DMF) between RE(NO3)3⋅6H2O (RE: Y3+, Tb3+, Dy3+, Ho3+, Er3+, and Yb3+) and H4 L in the presence of excess acetic acid and 2-FBA afforded high-quality hexagonal-shaped single crystals. However, the selection of twin-free small crystals resulted in poor single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD), except for the yttrium and holmium analogues, where a successful SCXRD analysis was executed (Tables S2 and S3). All of the other RE analogues were found isostructural on the basis of their powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns (Figure S3). The phase purity of each RE-csq-MOF-1 was confirmed by whole profile pattern matching using the Le Bail method (Figure S4). The crystal structure of the Y-analogue is described in detail below.

elements.content: The material, denoted here as Y-csq-MOF-1, crystallizes in the hexagonal system space group P 6/ mmm with unit cell a = b = 26.4725(14) Å, c = 16.6116(7) Å, V = 10081.7(11) Å3. Remarkably, this is a three-dimensional open structure based on a new, highly symmetric tetranuclear cluster, formulated as Y4(μ3-O)2(COO)8, with an overall charge-balanced framework formula Y4(μ3-O)2(DMF)2(H2O)4 L 2. Interestingly, no acetate or 2-fluorobenzoate anions were found coordinated on the Y-cluster, as confirmed by 1H NMR spectroscopy on an acid-digested, as-made sample (Figure S35). The inorganic SBU core, Y4(μ3-O)2, has a rhombic shape with planar D 2h symmetry, consisting of two crystallographically independent yttrium ions (Figure S7). One of them (Y1) is coordinated to two coplanar μ3-O groups (Y1–O3 bond length, 2.293 Å), four oxygens from four different carboxylate groups, one DMF, and one water molecule. The other one (Y2) is coordinated to one μ3-O group (Y2–O3 bond length, 2.276 Å), four oxygens from four carboxylate groups, and one water molecule. In each cluster, eight carboxylate groups from eight different organic linkers are coordinated in bidentate syn,syn-μ2 mode, making this an 8-c building block. Notably, although cuboid [RE4(μ3-OH)4]8+ and nonplanar, butterfly-like RE4(μ3-OH)2 clusters are known structural motifs in lanthanide complexes, to the best of our knowledge, the tetranuclear core [RE4(μ3-O)2]8+ with planar geometry is reported for the first time.
elements.clean_text: The material, denoted here as Y-csq-MOF-1, crystallizes in the hexagonal system space group  P 6/ mmm  with unit cell a = b = 26.4725(14) Å, c = 16.6116(7) Å, V = 10081.7(11) Å3. Remarkably, this is a three-dimensional open structure based on a new, highly symmetric tetranuclear cluster, formulated as Y4(μ3-O)2(COO)8, with an overall charge-balanced framework formula Y4(μ3-O)2(DMF)2(H2O)4 L 2. Interestingly, no acetate or 2-fluorobenzoate anions were found coordinated on the Y-cluster, as confirmed by 1H NMR spectroscopy on an acid-digested, as-made sample (Figure S35). The inorganic SBU core, Y4(μ3-O)2, has a rhombic shape with planar D 2h  symmetry, consisting of two crystallographically independent yttrium ions (Figure S7). One of them (Y1) is coordinated to two coplanar μ3-O groups (Y1-O3 bond length, 2.293 Å), four oxygens from four different carboxylate groups, one DMF, and one water molecule. The other one (Y2) is coordinated to one μ3-O group (Y2-O3 bond length, 2.276 Å), four oxygens from four carboxylate groups, and one water molecule. In each cluster, eight carboxylate groups from eight different organic linkers are coordinated in bidentate syn,syn-μ2 mode, making this an 8-c building block. Notably, although cuboid [RE4(μ3-OH)4]8+ and nonplanar, butterfly-like RE4(μ3-OH)2 clusters are known structural motifs in lanthanide complexes, to the best of our knowledge, the tetranuclear core [RE4(μ3-O)2]8+ with planar geometry is reported for the first time.

elements.content: The unique 8-c tetranuclear cluster Y4(μ3-O)2(COO)8 serves as an 8-c SBU and is combined with the 4-c rectangular organic linker, resulting in the formation of a (4, 8)-connected Y-csq-MOF-1 framework with the augmented csq topology (). It is noted that although this topology has been observed in important MOFs, including the well-known Zr-MOF NU-1000, it is observed for the first time in RE-MOFs. Interestingly, very recently, Eddaoudi and co-workers have reported the synthesis of (4, 12)-c Y-shp-MOF-5 based on a 12-c nonanuclear cluster, [Y9(μ3-O)2(μ3-OH)12(OH)2(O2C−)12]3–, using the rectangular ligand 1,2,4,5-tetrakis­(4-carboxyphenyl)­benzene as a 4-c organic MBB. This linker was also employed for the construction of the first Ce­(IV) (4, 8)-connected MOF with scu topology. The difference of this linker with our H4 L is the absence of the two methyl groups attached on the central phenyl ring, causing the four carboxyphenyl groups to be more flexible in terms of rotation because of the less steric effects. More specifically, the dihedral angle between a carboxylphenyl group and the central ring is 62.6° in Y-shp-MOF-5 and 63.5° in Ce-scu, whereas in Y-csq-MOF-1, it is 86° (Figure S9). In the free form of the two different linkers (nonmethylated and methylated), the corresponding dihedral angles predicted by density functional theory are 47.8 and 89.6° (Figure S9), demonstrating that our H4 L linker is a rigid organic MBB. It is important to note that in practicing reticular chemistry and the associated topology-guided synthesis the relative positioning of the coordinating groups (e.g., carboxylates) of the linker plays an important role, on top of other key geometric features, such as symmetry and connectivity. Given that the synthesis of the reported Y-shp-MOF-5 using the nonmethylated linker was performed under similar reaction conditions in the presence of excess 2-FBA as modulator, the isolation of the novel Y-csq-MOF-1 is attributed to the rigid nature of the organic linker H4 L. This is also strongly supported by the fact that we isolated isostructural analogues RE-csq-MOF-1 (RE: Tb3+, Dy3+, Ho3+, Er3+, and Yb3+) under the same reaction conditions.
elements.clean_text: The unique 8-c tetranuclear cluster Y4(μ3-O)2(COO)8 serves as an 8-c SBU and is combined with the 4-c rectangular organic linker, resulting in the formation of a (4, 8)-connected Y-csq-MOF-1 framework with the augmented csq topology (). It is noted that although this topology has been observed in important MOFs, including the well-known Zr-MOF NU-1000, it is observed for the first time in RE-MOFs. Interestingly, very recently, Eddaoudi and co-workers have reported the synthesis of (4, 12)-c Y-shp-MOF-5 based on a 12-c nonanuclear cluster, [Y9(μ3-O)2(μ3-OH)12(OH)2(O2C-)12]3-, using the rectangular ligand 1,2,4,5-tetrakis(4-carboxyphenyl)benzene as a 4-c organic MBB. This linker was also employed for the construction of the first Ce(IV) (4, 8)-connected MOF with scu topology. The difference of this linker with our H4 L is the absence of the two methyl groups attached on the central phenyl ring, causing the four carboxyphenyl groups to be more flexible in terms of rotation because of the less steric effects. More specifically, the dihedral angle between a carboxylphenyl group and the central ring is 62.6° in Y-shp-MOF-5 and 63.5° in Ce-scu, whereas in Y-csq-MOF-1, it is 86° (Figure S9). In the free form of the two different linkers (nonmethylated and methylated), the corresponding dihedral angles predicted by density functional theory are 47.8 and 89.6° (Figure S9), demonstrating that our H4 L linker is a rigid organic MBB. It is important to note that in practicing reticular chemistry and the associated topology-guided synthesis the relative positioning of the coordinating groups (e.g., carboxylates) of the linker plays an important role, on top of other key geometric features, such as symmetry and connectivity. Given that the synthesis of the reported Y-shp-MOF-5 using the nonmethylated linker was performed under similar reaction conditions in the presence of excess 2-FBA as modulator, the isolation of the novel Y-csq-MOF-1 is attributed to the rigid nature of the organic linker H4 L. This is also strongly supported by the fact that we isolated isostructural analogues RE-csq-MOF-1 (RE: Tb3+, Dy3+, Ho3+, Er3+, and Yb3+) under the same reaction conditions.

elements.content: The structure of Y-csq-MOF-1 features relatively large hexagonal channels running along the c axis of approximately 16 Å in diameter, surrounded by six smaller (∼6 Å) trigonal-shaped channels ( and S8). These channels are interconnected via rectangular-shaped windows (11 × 4 Å2) along the b axis, creating a three-dimensional pore system, which was found accessible, as confirmed experimentally by accurate microporous analysis using Ar at 87 K and described below. The material was found to be stable in air for at least 24 h and also in common organic solvents, including acetone, EtOH, MeOH, CH3CN, and CH2Cl2 (Figures S5 and S6). Activation of Y-csq-MOF-1 was successfully achieved by applying a straightforward procedure using acetone as a volatile solvent to exchange the DMF/H2O molecules, followed by drying under vacuum at room temperature (see Supporting Information). The complete removal of all solvent molecules was confirmed by 1H NMR on a digested, activated sample (Figure S36). Argon adsorption isotherm recorded at 87 K confirmed the permanent porosity of Y-csq-MOF-1, showing a fully reversible type-I isotherm, characteristic of a microporous material (see ). The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (Langmuir) surface area, calculated in the pressure range of 0.007–0.08 p/p o, was found to be 870 m2 g–1 (949 m2 g–1) (Figures S11 and S12), whereas the total pore volume at 0.98 p/p o is 0.37 cm3 g–1. The pore size distribution was calculated using nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT) after a successful fitting of the Ar adsorption isotherm data using a suitable NLDFT kernel (Figure S13). Accordingly, the corresponding curve shows three distinct peaks centered at 6.4, 11, and 16 Å, in agreement with the crystallographic analysis (, inset). Structural integrity of the activated material was confirmed by PXRD measurements (Figure S6). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of the activated sample under nitrogen flow revealed that there is no appreciable weight loss (<10%) up to 550 °C (Figure S10). This temperature is higher compared to the decomposition temperature of representative and highly connected RE-MOFs, including Y-alb-MOF-1 and Y-ftw-MOF-2, suggesting a high thermal stability of the activated Y-csq-MOF-1.
elements.clean_text: The structure of Y-csq-MOF-1 features relatively large hexagonal channels running along the c axis of approximately 16 Å in diameter, surrounded by six smaller (~6 Å) trigonal-shaped channels ( and S8). These channels are interconnected via rectangular-shaped windows (11 × 4 Å2) along the b axis, creating a three-dimensional pore system, which was found accessible, as confirmed experimentally by accurate microporous analysis using Ar at 87 K and described below. The material was found to be stable in air for at least 24 h and also in common organic solvents, including acetone, EtOH, MeOH, CH3CN, and CH2Cl2 (Figures S5 and S6). Activation of Y-csq-MOF-1 was successfully achieved by applying a straightforward procedure using acetone as a volatile solvent to exchange the DMF/H2O molecules, followed by drying under vacuum at room temperature (see Supporting Information). The complete removal of all solvent molecules was confirmed by 1H NMR on a digested, activated sample (Figure S36). Argon adsorption isotherm recorded at 87 K confirmed the permanent porosity of Y-csq-MOF-1, showing a fully reversible type-I isotherm, characteristic of a microporous material (see ). The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (Langmuir) surface area, calculated in the pressure range of 0.007-0.08 p/p o, was found to be 870 m2 g-1 (949 m2 g-1) (Figures S11 and S12), whereas the total pore volume at 0.98 p/p o is 0.37 cm3 g-1. The pore size distribution was calculated using nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT) after a successful fitting of the Ar adsorption isotherm data using a suitable NLDFT kernel (Figure S13). Accordingly, the corresponding curve shows three distinct peaks centered at 6.4, 11, and 16 Å, in agreement with the crystallographic analysis (, inset). Structural integrity of the activated material was confirmed by PXRD measurements (Figure S6). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of the activated sample under nitrogen flow revealed that there is no appreciable weight loss (<10%) up to 550 °C (Figure S10). This temperature is higher compared to the decomposition temperature of representative and highly connected RE-MOFs, including Y-alb-MOF-1 and Y-ftw-MOF-2, suggesting a high thermal stability of the activated Y-csq-MOF-1.

elements.content: Argon sorption isotherm at 87 K for Y-csq-MOF-1 and the corresponding pore size distribution curve calculated by NLDFT (inset).
elements.clean_text: 2  Argon sorption isotherm at 87 K for Y-csq-MOF-1 and the corresponding pore size distribution curve calculated by NLDFT (inset).

elements.content: In the activated Y-csq-MOF-1, the large number of unsaturated Y­(III)-sites resulting from the removal of the coordinated solvent molecules and the relatively high accessible micropore volume prompted us to investigate its performance in Xe/Kr separation. Adsorption-based separation of Xe over Kr is considered ideal over the currently used cryogenic distillation, and MOFs are excellent candidates compared to more traditional porous materials, including zeolites and activated carbon. To this end, MOFs with channel-like pore system, such as Y-csq-MOF-1, are preferable due to the efficient packing of Xe atoms. The Xe and Kr adsorption isotherms recorded at 273, 283, and 298 K up to 1 bar are shown in . The Xe isotherms show a relatively steep uptake at low pressures, followed by a gradual increase with increasing pressure, reaching 75.5 cm3 g–1 (3.37 mmol g–1), 63.0 cm–3 g–1 (2.81 mmol g–1), and 43.4 cm–3 g–1 (1.94 mmol g–1) at 273, 283, and 298 K, respectively, at 1 bar. In contrast, the corresponding Kr isotherms show no steep adsorption at low pressures and a significantly reduced uptake at 1 bar, reaching 35.0 cm3 g–1 (1.56 mmol g–1), 24.2 cm–3 g–1 (1.08 mmol g–1), and 13.8 cm–3 g–1 (0.62 mmol g–1) at 273, 283, and 298 K, respectively. These results suggest a preferable adsorption of Xe over Kr in Y-csq-MOF-1 and are confirmed by calculating the corresponding isosteric heat of adsorption (Q st). Accordingly, using a virial-type equation, the Q st value at zero coverage (Q st o) for Xe is 33.8 kJ mol–1 and slightly decreases with increasing surface coverage, whereas for Kr, the Q st o value is 30.8 kJ mol–1 and remains constant as a function of surface coverage (Figures S15 and S17). Notably, the observed Q st o value for Xe is higher compared to the best-performing MOFs studied for Xe adsorption, including Co3(HCOO)6 (28.0 kJ mol–1), CC3 (27.8 kJ mol–1), Noria (26.9 kJ mol–1), HKUST-1 (26.9 kJ mol–1), and SBMOF-2 (26.4 kJ mol–1) (Figure S18). The IAST Xe/Kr selectivities calculated for a 10/90 molar mixture, which is relevant for practical applications, are 13.1, 12.2, and 12.1 at 273, 283, and 298 K, respectively, at the low-pressure range and slightly decreases with increasing pressure (Figure S25). The IAST Xe/Kr selectivity at 298 K is among the top-performing materials (c). For comparison purposes, under dilute conditions, the Xe/Kr selectivity at 298 K calculated as the ratio of the corresponding Henry coefficients (10.6 and 0.82 mmol g–1 bar–1 for Xe and Kr, respectively) is 12.9, placing Y-csq-MOF-1 in the second position on the list of the best-performing sorbents for Xe/Kr separation from nuclear reprocessing applications, including SBMOF-1 (16.2), CC3 (12.8), Co3(HCOO)6 (10.7), Noria (9.4), SBMOF-2 (8.6), and HKUST-1 (8.5) (c). However, for this kind of application, the Xe uptake is also important, and compared to the leading material SBMOF-1, Y-csq-MOF-1 shows higher Xe uptake at 298 K and 1 bar (1.94 vs 1.38 mmol g–1), due to its higher surface area (870 vs 145 m2 g–1).

Adsorption-based separation of Xe over Kr is considered ideal over the currently used cryogenic distillation, and MOFs are excellent candidates compared to more traditional porous materials, including zeolites and activated carbon. To this end, MOFs with channel-like pore system, such as Y-csq-MOF-1, are preferable due to the efficient packing of Xe atoms. The Xe and Kr adsorption isotherms recorded at 273, 283, and 298 K up to 1 bar are shown in . The Xe isotherms show a relatively steep uptake at low pressures, followed by a gradual increase with increasing pressure, reaching 75.5 cm3 g-1 (3.37 mmol g-1), 63.0 cm-3 g-1 (2.81 mmol g-1), and 43.4 cm-3 g-1 (1.94 mmol g-1) at 273, 283, and 298 K, respectively, at 1 bar. In contrast, the corresponding Kr isotherms show no steep adsorption at low pressures and a significantly reduced uptake at 1 bar, reaching 35.0 cm3 g-1 (1.56 mmol g-1), 24.2 cm-3 g-1 (1.08 mmol g-1), and 13.8 cm-3 g-1 (0.62 mmol g-1) at 273, 283, and 298 K, respectively. These results suggest a preferable adsorption of Xe over Kr in Y-csq-MOF-1 and are confirmed by calculating the corresponding isosteric heat of adsorption (Q st). Accordingly, using a virial-type equation, the Q st value at zero coverage (Q st o) for Xe is 33.8 kJ mol-1 and slightly decreases with increasing surface coverage, whereas for Kr, the Q st o value is 30.8 kJ mol-1 and remains constant as a function of surface coverage (Figures S15 and S17). The IAST Xe/Kr selectivities calculated for a 10/90 molar mixture, which is relevant for practical applications, are 13.1, 12.2, and 12.1 at 273, 283, and 298 K, respectively, at the low-pressure range and slightly decreases with increasing pressure (Figure S25). However, for this kind of application, the Xe uptake is also important, and compared to the leading material SBMOF-1, Y-csq-MOF-1 shows higher Xe uptake at 298 K and 1 bar (1.94 vs 1.38 mmol g-1), due to its higher surface area (870 vs 145 m2 g-1).

elements.content: Xe (a) and Kr (b) adsorption isotherms at 273, 283, and 298 K, up to 1 bar. (c) Xe/Kr selectivity at 298 K of Y-csq-MOF-1 compared with top-performing MOFs.
elements.clean_text: 3  Xe (a) and Kr (b) adsorption isotherms at 273, 283, and 298 K, up to 1 bar. (c) Xe/Kr selectivity at 298 K of Y-csq-MOF-1 compared with top-performing MOFs.

elements.content: We have also recorded CO2, CH4, and N2 adsorption isotherms at 273, 283, and 298 up to 1 bar, from which the corresponding Q st and CO2/CH4 and CO2/N2 IAST selectivities were calculated. Accordingly, a moderate CO2 uptake is observed, reaching 61.7 cm3 g–1 (2.75 mmol g–1), 46.9 cm3 g–1 (2.09 mmol g–1), and 30.8 cm3 g–1 (1.37 mmol g–1) at 273, 283, and 298 K, respectively, whereas for CH4, the corresponding values are 31.2 cm3 g–1 (1.39 mmol g–1), 24.1 cm3 g–1 (1.07 mmol g–1), and 11.1 cm3 g–1 (0.5 mmol g–1) (Figures S26 and S29). Using a virial-type equation, the calculated Q st o values are 30 and 27.1 kJ mol–1 for CO2 and CH4, respectively (Figures S28 and S31). These values are comparable to those reported for Y-ftw-MOF-2, under similar conditions. The moderate CO2 uptake and relatively high Q st o value for CH4 resulted in a low CO2/CH4 selectivity, between 3 and 4, as calculated by IAST for a 5/95 molar mixture (Figure S32). A higher CO2/N2 selectivity was observed, having values of 6.7, 8, and 11.7 at 273, 283, and 298 K respectively, which remain constant as a function of surface coverage (Figure S34).
elements.clean_text: We have also recorded CO2, CH4, and N2 adsorption isotherms at 273, 283, and 298 up to 1 bar, from which the corresponding Q st and CO2/CH4 and CO2/N2 IAST selectivities were calculated. Accordingly, a moderate CO2 uptake is observed, reaching 61.7 cm3 g-1 (2.75 mmol g-1), 46.9 cm3 g-1 (2.09 mmol g-1), and 30.8 cm3 g-1 (1.37 mmol g-1) at 273, 283, and 298 K, respectively, whereas for CH4, the corresponding values are 31.2 cm3 g-1 (1.39 mmol g-1), 24.1 cm3 g-1 (1.07 mmol g-1), and 11.1 cm3 g-1 (0.5 mmol g-1) (Figures S26 and S29). Using a virial-type equation, the calculated Q st o values are 30 and 27.1 kJ mol-1 for CO2 and CH4, respectively (Figures S28 and S31). These values are comparable to those reported for Y-ftw-MOF-2, under similar conditions. The moderate CO2 uptake and relatively high Q st o value for CH4 resulted in a low CO2/CH4 selectivity, between 3 and 4, as calculated by IAST for a 5/95 molar mixture (Figure S32). A higher CO2/N2 selectivity was observed, having values of 6.7, 8, and 11.7 at 273, 283, and 298 K respectively, which remain constant as a function of surface coverage (Figure S34).

elements.content: We have successfully synthesized a new family of RE-MOFs on the basis of the novel inorganic building unit RE4(μ3-O)2, following reticular chemistry rules and the MBB approach. We designed a rigid 4-c linker, H4 L, that serves as an organic MBB and directs the in situ assembly of the unique 8-c RE4(μ3-O)2(COO)8 cluster, resulting in the formation of the first (4, 8)-c RE-MOFs with the augmented csq topology, RE-csq-MOF-1. The distinct structural and pore characteristics of RE-csq-MOF-1 expand the available RE-MOF platforms and provide additional opportunities for various applications, including gas storage/separation, catalysis, sensing, and imaging. To demonstrate this, Y-csq-MOF-1 was successfully activated and tested for Xe/Kr separation. The results show that Y-csq-MOF-1 have very high isosteric heat of adsorption for Xe (33.8 kJ mol–1), with high Xe/Kr selectivity (12.1) and good Xe uptake (1.94 mmol g–1 at 298 K and 1 bar), placing this MOF among the top-performing adsorbents for Xe/Kr separation.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

We have successfully synthesized a new family of RE-MOFs on the basis of the novel inorganic building unit RE4(μ3-O)2, following reticular chemistry rules and the MBB approach. We designed a rigid 4-c linker, H4 L, that serves as an organic MBB and directs the in situ assembly of the unique 8-c RE4(μ3-O)2(COO)8 cluster, resulting in the formation of the first (4, 8)-c RE-MOFs with the augmented csq topology, RE-csq-MOF-1. The distinct structural and pore characteristics of RE-csq-MOF-1 expand the available RE-MOF platforms and provide additional opportunities for various applications, including gas storage/separation, catalysis, sensing, and imaging. To demonstrate this, Y-csq-MOF-1 was successfully activated and tested for Xe/Kr separation. The results show that Y-csq-MOF-1 have very high isosteric heat of adsorption for Xe (33.8 kJ mol-1), with high Xe/Kr selectivity (12.1) and good Xe uptake (1.94 mmol g-1 at 298 K and 1 bar), placing this MOF among the top-performing adsorbents for Xe/Kr separation.

cln_elements.content:
The material, denoted here as Y-csq-MOF-1, crystallizes in the hexagonal system space group P 6/ mmm with unit cell a = b = 26.4725(14) Å, c = 16.6116(7) Å, V = 10081.7(11) Å3. Remarkably, this is a three-dimensional open structure based on a new, highly symmetric tetranuclear cluster, formulated as Y4(μ3-O)2(COO)8, with an overall charge-balanced framework formula Y4(μ3-O)2(DMF)2(H2O)4 L 2. Interestingly, no acetate or 2-fluorobenzoate anions were found coordinated on the Y-cluster, as confirmed by 1H NMR spectroscopy on an acid-digested, as-made sample (Figure S35). The inorganic SBU core, Y4(μ3-O)2, has a rhombic shape with planar D 2h symmetry, consisting of two crystallographically independent yttrium ions (Figure S7). One of them (Y1) is coordinated to two coplanar μ3-O groups (Y1–O3 bond length, 2.293 Å), four oxygens from four different carboxylate groups, one DMF, and one water molecule. The other one (Y2) is coordinated to one μ3-O group (Y2–O3 bond length, 2.276 Å), four oxygens from four carboxylate groups, and one water molecule. In each cluster, eight carboxylate groups from eight different organic linkers are coordinated in bidentate syn,syn-μ2 mode, making this an 8-c building block. Notably, although cuboid [RE4(μ3-OH)4]8+ and nonplanar, butterfly-like RE4(μ3-OH)2 clusters are known structural motifs in lanthanide complexes, to the best of our knowledge, the tetranuclear core [RE4(μ3-O)2]8+ with planar geometry is reported for the first time.

The structure of Y-csq-MOF-1 features relatively large hexagonal channels running along the c axis of approximately 16 Å in diameter, surrounded by six smaller (∼6 Å) trigonal-shaped channels ( and S8). These channels are interconnected via rectangular-shaped windows (11 × 4 Å2) along the b axis, creating a three-dimensional pore system, which was found accessible, as confirmed experimentally by accurate microporous analysis using Ar at 87 K and described below. The material was found to be stable in air for at least 24 h and also in common organic solvents, including acetone, EtOH, MeOH, CH3CN, and CH2Cl2 (Figures S5 and S6). Activation of Y-csq-MOF-1 was successfully achieved by applying a straightforward procedure using acetone as a volatile solvent to exchange the DMF/H2O molecules, followed by drying under vacuum at room temperature (see Supporting Information). The complete removal of all solvent molecules was confirmed by 1H NMR on a digested, activated sample (Figure S36). Argon adsorption isotherm recorded at 87 K confirmed the permanent porosity of Y-csq-MOF-1, showing a fully reversible type-I isotherm, characteristic of a microporous material (see ). The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (Langmuir) surface area, calculated in the pressure range of 0.007–0.08 p/p o, was found to be 870 m2 g–1 (949 m2 g–1) (Figures S11 and S12), whereas the total pore volume at 0.98 p/p o is 0.37 cm3 g–1. The pore size distribution was calculated using nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT) after a successful fitting of the Ar adsorption isotherm data using a suitable NLDFT kernel (Figure S13). Accordingly, the corresponding curve shows three distinct peaks centered at 6.4, 11, and 16 Å, in agreement with the crystallographic analysis (, inset). Structural integrity of the activated material was confirmed by PXRD measurements (Figure S6). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of the activated sample under nitrogen flow revealed that there is no appreciable weight loss (<10%) up to 550 °C (Figure S10). This temperature is higher compared to the decomposition temperature of representative and highly connected RE-MOFs, including Y-alb-MOF-1 and Y-ftw-MOF-2, suggesting a high thermal stability of the activated Y-csq-MOF-1.

This temperature is higher compared to the decomposition temperature of representative and highly connected RE-MOFs, including Y-alb-MOF-1 and Y-ftw-MOF-2, suggesting a high thermal stability of the activated Y-csq-MOF-1.

cln_elements.content: Combination of the novel 8-c tetranuclear clusters RE4(μ3-O)2(-COO)8 (a) with the 4-c rectangular H4 L ligand (b) leads to the construction of RE-csq-MOF-1 series (c), displaying the augment csq-a net.

metadata.title:
Reticular
Chemistry and the Discovery of a New Family of Rare Earth (4, 8)-Connected
Metal-Organic Frameworks with csq Topology Based on RE4(μ3‑O)2(COO)8 Clusters
